title.narrative: Enhanced Response Capacity for the Responsible and Safe Sharing of Data about Crisis-Affected People

description.narrative: Humanitarian organizations are collecting and sharing more data than ever before. This trend will continue as more systems, sensors and people come online in crisis settings. How the humanitarian community handles the data revolution to inform decisions and improve lives will be a key determinant of its future effectiveness.The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) and the United Nations Office for Project Services (UNOPS) jointly propose this global project to facilitate the responsible and safe sharing of data about crisis-affected people, enhancing efficiency and transparency throughout the humanitarian programme cycle as well as contributing to accountability to affected populations.Humanitarian data can be considered high risk when it identifies individuals, communities or demographics within a group and ties them to a place (i.e. women of a certain age group in a specific location). Work must be done to build data responsibility into the daily practices of humanitarian organizations, especially in light of recent data breaches in the sector and with the coming into force of the EU's Global Data Protection Regulations on 25 May 2018. OCHA, which is mandated to coordinate humanitarian response, is an ideal partner for DG ECHO's efforts to promote better ways of managing information in emergencies.The results of this project will be:the development and prototyping of a secure technical infrastructure that will allow key partners to process and share sensitive data responsibly via HDX;the drafting and distribution of guidelines on managing personal or sensitive data for the humanitarian sector; andat least two events focused on responsible data use in the humanitarian sector with partners from the private sector, academia, government, and IASC agencies.
